bibl.title: Letter from E.J. Scannell to Henry Rose Carter, July 7, 1922

div1.p: Scannell discusses his field work and answers Carter's questions concerning the breeding places of mosquitoes in wells.

div1.head: Letter from E.J. Scannell to Henry Rose Carter, July 7, 1922
div1.opener:
DEPARTAMENTO DE SALUBRIDAD PUBLICA
COMISION ESPECIAL PARA LA CAMPAÑA
CONTRA LA FIEBRE AMARILLA
____
OFICINA EN TAPACHULA, CHIAPAS.
APARTADO 42.
____
I H. B.
Scannell
July 7, 1922.
Doctor H. R. Carter,
Assistant Surgeon-General,
United States Public Health Service,
Washington, D. C.
Dear Doctor Carter;
div1.p:
I received your letter July 5th. after it had been forwarded
from both N.Y. and Vera Cruz.

I have the percentage of house breeding down now to
about 3 and there it remains- at times it drops to 2 1/2
but not to stay. The town is putting in a new water system
which will fix things permanently I think- many of the
people either buy water or carry it long distances now
and are loathe to parting with it. Another factor keeping
up the rate is the rain - the rainy season started in
April and has been very heavy at times, as a result we
are finding breeders in all sorts of places in the patios-
in old cocoanut shells, holes in tree's and the like.
I remember you cautioned in one of your articles about
holes in tree trunks, banana tree's and the like as
possible breeding places. Driving them out of the houses
forces them naturally to these other places. Our gutter
problem has caused very little trouble here, one reason
and possibly the chief, being the water is too hot - at
times it is nearly warm enough to cook an egg - however
I caution our inspectors to take nothing for granted
but to inspect them anyway.

DEPARTAMENTO DE SALUBRIDAD PUBLICA
COMISION ESPECIAL PARA LA CAMPAÑA
CONTRA LA FIEBRE AMARILLA
____
OFICINA EN TAPACHULA, CHIAPAS.
APARTADO 42.
____
I shall attempt to answer your questions-

1. You ask about the breeding in wells-
We drop a bucket to the bottom of the well, allow it to
remain for three to five minutes and then suddenly pull
it up the side and if they are there we find them usually.
Many of the wells would have both swarms of stegomyias (adults)
as well as the larvae - I have seen some of the buckets just
black with larvae (stegomyia). I mean of course the water in
the bucket and frequently here we find the stegomya in
association with a brown culex which I think is the pipiens.

2. The width of the wells is about four feet on the average
some wider.

I do not know the temperature of water. I do know that
during March, April and May it is not very cold for nearly
all the wells are open to the sun and this is one of the
hottest places I was ever in. I have not been able to get
a thermometer in town to try out the water but hope to
do so later and will try give you an idea as to the probable
temperature- this town has very little in way of the most
ordinary every day appliances.

3. The fish in wells we can see at times when the light is
right - the people as a rule are very proud of their fish
and at once inform us if everything is not alright - should
the fish die they ask for more since now they realize what
their presence means - once in awhile they bring them up
in a bucket of water. I I am not using bottom feedess
since I have to use what I can get and my regular supply
DEPARTAMENTO DE SALUBRIDAD PUBLICA
COMISION ESPECIAL PARA LA CAMPAÑA
CONTRA LA FIEBRE AMARILLA
____
3. OFICINA EN TAPACHULA, CHIAPAS.
APARTADO 42.
____
consists of pupos, mojarritos, sardinas, truchas and another
variety unclassified but a very good one since it is very
greedy and feeds top, bottom and the middle - in fact on
testing them out I find the pupos or truchas are very good
and provided they are not fed will eat top, bottom and middle.
We caution our people about feeding them - they (the people)
feel they should feed them but we tell them no and as
a result the wells have been cleared of breeding in short
order - of course another factor has entered in now, the
cooler weather, no doubt that is helping us.

I am sending some specimens of fish to the Board for
classification - the local people can give me no reliable
information except that they are fish.

I did not know how Dr. White found out my address - thank you
for informing him. I was in North Dakota attempting to help
reorganize the State Board of Health and the temperature was
running about 20 below- had been there only three months.
Please tell Miss. Carter that we shall more than appreciate
her book also please tell her I had not forgotten her promise.
Mrs. Scannell is at the cottage - Passetemps Cottage, Bridgewater,
New Hampshire. We usually spend the summer there, at least when I
am up. The “Songs of the Long Trail” sounds like Panama.

Please extend my kindest regards to all the members of your
family. I expect to see Dr. White in the next few days since
some mail arrived here to-day for him, so evidently he is near by.
div1.closer: Very respectfully yours, E. J. Scannell.
